RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Possui graduao em Licenciatura Plena em Fsica pela Faculdade de Cincias Aplicadas de So Jos dos Campos (2006) e mestrado em Geofsica Espacial pelo Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (2011). Atualmente controlador de satlite do Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais e doutorando em Geofsica Espacial no Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais desde 2015. Tem experincia na rea de Engenharia Aeroespacial, com nfase em Satlites e Outros Dispositivos Aeroespaciais,
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: graduation at Licenciatura Plena em Fsica from Faculdade de Cincias Aplicadas de So Jos dos Campos (2006) and master's at Geophysics from Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais (2011). Has experience in Aerospace Engineering, focusing on Satellites and Other Aerospace Devices

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Continuing current in negative cloud-to-ground flashes

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: GROUND 2010 International Conference on Grounding and Earthing & 4th LPE - International Conference on Ligthning Physics and Effects
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: GROUND 2010 International Conference on Grounding and Earthing & 4th LPE - International Conference on Ligthning Physics and Effects

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-3.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Fsica dos Fludos, Fsica de Plasmas e Descargas Eltricas

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Continuing current is the continuous mode of charge transfer to ground in a flash. The extent to which the continuing current (CC) contributes to the total negative charged lowered to earth is large. They are responsible for most serious lightning damage associated with thermal effects. From the analysis of digital high-speed video records of more than 600 negative cloud-to-ground (CG) lightning flashes in Brazil, various continuing current properties have been determined. The data were obtained through summer seasons from 2003 to 2010. The videos are compared with data obtained by Brazilian Lightning Location System (BrasilDat) in order to determine the polarity of each flash, current peak and ranging. The topics analyzed in this study are: duration distribution of CC, percentage of flashes and strokes containing CC, relation between the stroke peak current and the duration of the following CC, relation between the duration of the CC and the interstroke time interval preceding the stroke initiating a CC, and stroke order dependence

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: First measurements of continuing current intensity in positive ground flashes

DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.NOME-DO-EVENTO: GROUND 2010 International Conference on Grounding and Earthing & 4th LPE - International Conference on Ligthning Physics and Effects
DETALHAMENTO-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DOS-ANAIS-OU-PROCEEDINGS: GROUND 2010 International Conference on Grounding and Earthing & 4th LPE - International Conference on Ligthning Physics and Effects

AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO-2.NOME-DA-SUB-AREA-DO-CONHECIMENTO: Fsica dos Fludos, Fsica de Plasmas e Descargas Eltricas

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: The highest directly measured lightning currents and the largest charge transfers to ground are thought to be associated with positive lightning. Positive strokes may have high peak currents followed by long continuing current (CC), and thus combine these two threatening features for lightning protection. Although positive flashes are usually less frequent than negative lightning, the special characteristics of their CC make the understanding of positive lightning an important issue. This study presents some CC intensity estimates obtained from electric field capacitive antenna. It also compares the waveshape of the CC intensity with luminosity measurements made from the images of two different high-speed digital video cameras (Photron Fastcam 512 PCI, Red Lake Motion Scope 8000S) with resolutions and exposure times between 125 microseconds (8,000 frames per second) and 1 ms (1,000 frames per second). Positive lightning were recorded in southeastern Brazil during the summer of 2009/2010. Images were GPS synchronized, time stamped and recorded without any frame-to-frame image persistence. This synchronization allowed the correlation of each flash recorded with the ones detected by the lightning locating system. Thus, it was possible to determine the distance of the stroke preceding each CC event to the antenna. Most CC intensities were much higher than the usual intensity values of CC in negative flashes.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-TRABALHO.TITULO-DO-TRABALHO: Lightning location system detection efficiency of negative cloud-to-ground strokes containing continuing current

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Frequency distributions of some parameters of negative downward lightning flashes based on accurate-stroke-count studies
Day-to-day differences in the characterization of lightning observed by multiple high-speed cameras

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This study aims to analyze how the visible parameters of cloud-to-ground discharges such as the flash multiplicity and duration, the interstroke interval, the continuing current duration and the number of ground contacts per flash vary between observations conducted on different days. Several authors have already analyzed these parameters for groups of thunderstorms in some regions. Although some authors did not find differences on those characteristics for different regions, there has not been a comprehensive amount of lightning recordings from the same thunderstorm in order to evaluate such parameters in a storm-to-storm basis. The lightning data for this work was obtained by four high-speed cameras set to operate at 2500 frames per second. They were located in So Jos dos Campos, Brazil, and in its neighboring region as part of the RAMMER project (Portuguese acronym for Automated Multi-Camera Network for Monitoring and Study of Lightning Flashes). Five thunderstorm days were selected for this study, during which a total of 361 flashes were recorded. This is the first study in which four high-speed cameras observed the same thunderstorm from different locations. Because of the number of cameras and their positions, the coverage area is larger than usual single-camera studies, thereby increasing the number of flashes recorded from the same thunderstorm. These larger samples allow a more representative analysis of the lightning parameters mentioned above.

DADOS-BASICOS-DO-ARTIGO.TITULO-DO-ARTIGO: Frequency distributions of some parameters of negative downward lightning flashes based on accurate-stroke-count studies

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This paper presents some parameters of negative cloud-to-ground lightning flashes in terms of frequency distribution. All data are based on so called "accurate-stroke-count studies" [Rakov and Huffines, 2003] from different climatological regions in the world and were already published in the literature with the exception of our measurements. We used GPS synchronized data from two digital high-speed cameras (@ 1-8,000 frames/sec). The parameters considered in this study are: (a) continuing current duration, (b) time intervals between strokes, (c) number of strokes per flash and (d) total flash duration. The analysis includes Berger's data of Monte San Salvatore (Switzerland), which is the basis for lightning protection standards. The comparison suggests that despite of overall agreement of those parameters that some of them, currently used in protection standards, should be revised in order to be more realistic.
